also that a speculum of Metal made for optical purposes 
produced none of these Rings, & thence I concluded that those 
Rings arise not from one specular surface alone, but 
depend upon the two surfaces, & upon the thickness of the 
plate of glass between them” He has already said “that 
the bright yellow light of the first Ring formed between 
two Lenses is transmitted when the thicknesses of the plate 
of Air is the 1/89000 part of an inch. lessening this thick-
ness in the proportion of the sine of refraction to the 
sine of incidence, that is as 11 to 17 (according to the 10th 
observation of the first part) when its thickness will be 
the 1/137545 part of an inch. if this thickness is doubled, 
it transmits the light of the 2d Ring, trebled it transmits 
that of the 3d &c and if multiplied by 34386 it gives exactly 
one Quarter of an inch.”
This yellow light he supposes to be the same with that 
which <s>that which <\s> is transmitted through the silvered speculum 
from its convex side to the center of the rings of colours on 
the card. and on measuring the thickness of the glass 
& finding it exactly one Quarter of an inch, he thence 
concludes that the Experiment confirms the Theory. 
but the admission of this conclusion must be entirely gratu-
itous, since an error of the 137545th part of an inch 
would make the Theory & the Experiment disagree; & yet 
a mistake 50 times greater might have been made without 
being perceived; for surely it would be difficult to avoid an 
error in the measurement of the thickness of the speculum, 
so small as the 2750th part of an inch.
